articles.title: Gargantuan black hole may be a remnant from the dawn of the universe
articles.summary: Astronomers were puzzled by a black hole around 50 million times the mass of the sun with no stars, spotted by the James Webb Space Telescope – now simulations suggest it could be a primordial black hole, something we have never seen before
articles.content:
Astronomers were puzzled by a black hole around 50 million times the mass of the sun with no stars, spotted by the James Webb Space Telescope – now simulations suggest it could be a primordial black hole, something we have never seen before

Primordial black holes are hypothesised to have formed shortly after the big bang Shutterstock/Mohd. Afuza

An unusually massive black hole in the very early universe may be a kind of exotic, star-less black hole first theorised by Stephen Hawking.

In August, Boyuan Liu at the University of Cambridge and his colleagues spotted a strange galaxy from 13 billion years ago, called Abell 2744-QSO1, with the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST). The galaxy appeared to host an enormous black hole, around 50 million times the mass of the sun, but it was almost entirely devoid of stars.

“This is a puzzle, because the traditional theory says that you form stars first, or together with black holes,” says Liu. Black holes are typically thought to form from very massive stars when they run out of fuel and collapse.

Liu and his team ran some basic simulations, which showed that QSO1 could have instead started out as a primordial black hole, an exotic object first put forward by physicists Stephen Hawking and Bernard Carr in 1974. Rather than forming from a star, these objects would have coalesced out of fluctuations in the universe’s density shortly after the big bang.

Primordial black holes should have largely evaporated and disappeared by the time we can see back to with JWST, but there is a chance that some may have survived and grown into much larger black holes, like QSO1.

While Liu and his team’s calculations roughly matched their observations, they were simple, and didn’t take into account the complex interplay between the primordial black holes, clouds of gas and stars.

Now, Liu and his team have run more detailed simulations of how primordial black holes would have grown in the universe’s first hundreds of millions of years. They calculated both how the gas would have swirled around a small, initial primordial black hole, and also how newly formed stars and dying stars would have interacted with it.

Their predictions for the final mass of the black hole and the heavier elements in it match what they observed for QSO1.

“It’s not decisive, but it’s an interesting and a kind of important possibility,” says Liu. “With these new observations that normal [black hole formation] theories struggle to reproduce, the possibility of having massive primordial black holes in the early universe becomes more permissible.”

The simulations show that primordial black holes could actually be a viable source for QSO1, says Roberto Maiolino at the University of Cambridge, who was part of the team that originally discovered the black hole. “The fact that they manage to match the properties of QSO1, both in terms of the black hole mass, the stellar mass and the chemical enrichment, is very interesting and encouraging.”

However, the largest supermassive black holes in standard primordial black hole simulations tend to be around 1 million solar masses, says Maiolino. “Here we are 50 times more massive,” he says. “However, it is true that these primordial black holes are expected to be strongly clustered, and so it may well be that they managed to merge to quickly become much more massive.”

Another problem is that primordial black holes should require a blast of high-energy radiation to initially collapse and form, such as a nearby exploding star, but we don’t see any potential sources anywhere close to QSO1, says Maiolino.

This finding advances our understanding of the early universe and black hole formation, representing a meaningful breakthrough in space science with broad implications for cosmology.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers spot possible ancient black hole from universe’s dawn
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists are studying black holes, which are huge objects in space with gravity so strong that nothing can escape. Most black holes form when big stars collapse. But some black holes might have formed right after the universe began, called primordial black holes. These have never been seen clearly before.

**What happened** – In August, a team led by Boyuan Liu at the University of Cambridge used the James Webb Space Telescope to look at a very old galaxy from 13 billion years ago, named Abell 2744-QSO1. They found a massive black hole there, about 50 million times heavier than our sun. What surprised them was that this black hole had almost no stars around it, which is unusual. The team ran computer simulations to understand this and suggested that this black hole might be primordial, meaning it formed soon after the Big Bang, not from a star.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it challenges what scientists thought about how black holes form. Usually, black holes and stars form together, but this black hole seems to have formed alone very early in the universe. If confirmed, it would be the first clear evidence of primordial black holes. This helps scientists learn more about the early universe and how these mysterious objects might grow over time.

**What's next step** – The researchers plan to improve their simulations to better understand how gas and stars interact with primordial black holes. They also want to find more black holes like this one to see if other ancient, star-less black holes exist. This could help confirm if primordial black holes are real and how they evolved.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A giant black hole found in a distant, star-less galaxy might be the first example of a primordial black hole formed just after the universe began, opening new paths to study the cosmos.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes découvrent un trou noir ancien datant de l’aube de l’univers
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les trous noirs, d’énormes objets dans l’espace avec une gravité si forte que rien ne peut s’en échapper. La plupart des trous noirs se forment lorsque de grosses étoiles s’effondrent. Mais certains pourraient s’être formés juste après le début de l’univers, appelés trous noirs primordiaux. Ceux-ci n’ont jamais été clairement observés.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En août, une équipe dirigée par Boyuan Liu de l’Université de Cambridge a utilisé le télescope spatial James Webb pour observer une galaxie très ancienne datant de 13 milliards d’années, nommée Abell 2744-QSO1. Ils ont découvert un trou noir massif, environ 50 millions de fois plus lourd que notre soleil. Ce qui les a surpris, c’est que ce trou noir était presque dépourvu d’étoiles autour, ce qui est inhabituel. L’équipe a réalisé des simulations informatiques et a suggéré que ce trou noir pourrait être primordiale, c’est-à-dire formé peu après le Big Bang, et non à partir d’une étoile.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle remet en question la façon dont les scientifiques pensent que les trous noirs se forment. Habituellement, les trous noirs et les étoiles se forment ensemble, mais ce trou noir semble s’être formé seul très tôt dans l’univers. S’il est confirmé, ce serait la première preuve claire de trous noirs primordiaux. Cela aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre l’univers primitif et comment ces objets mystérieux ont pu grandir.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs prévoient d’améliorer leurs simulations pour mieux comprendre comment le gaz et les étoiles interagissent avec les trous noirs primordiaux. Ils veulent aussi trouver d’autres trous noirs similaires pour voir si d’autres trous noirs anciens sans étoiles existent. Cela pourrait confirmer si les trous noirs primordiaux sont réels et comment ils ont évolué.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Un trou noir géant trouvé dans une galaxie lointaine sans étoiles pourrait être le premier exemple d’un trou noir primordial formé juste après le début de l’univers, ouvrant de nouvelles voies pour étudier le cosmos.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos detectan posible agujero negro antiguo del amanecer del universo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian los agujeros negros, que son objetos enormes en el espacio con una gravedad tan fuerte que nada puede escapar. La mayoría de los agujeros negros se forman cuando estrellas grandes colapsan. Pero algunos podrían haberse formado justo después de que comenzó el universo, llamados agujeros negros primordiales. Estos nunca se han visto claramente.

**Qué pasó** – En agosto, un equipo liderado por Boyuan Liu de la Universidad de Cambridge usó el telescopio espacial James Webb para observar una galaxia muy antigua de hace 13 mil millones de años, llamada Abell 2744-QSO1. Encontraron un agujero negro enorme, unas 50 millones de veces más pesado que nuestro sol. Lo sorprendente fue que este agujero negro tenía casi ninguna estrella a su alrededor, algo poco común. El equipo hizo simulaciones por computadora y sugirió que este agujero negro podría ser primordial, es decir, formado poco después del Big Bang, no a partir de una estrella.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque desafía lo que los científicos pensaban sobre cómo se forman los agujeros negros. Normalmente, los agujeros negros y las estrellas se forman juntos, pero este parece haberse formado solo muy temprano en el universo. Si se confirma, sería la primera evidencia clara de agujeros negros primordiales. Esto ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor el universo temprano y cómo estos objetos misteriosos crecieron.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean mejorar sus simulaciones para entender mejor cómo el gas y las estrellas interactúan con los agujeros negros primordiales. También quieren encontrar más agujeros negros como este para ver si existen otros antiguos sin estrellas. Esto podría ayudar a confirmar si los agujeros negros primordiales son reales y cómo evolucionaron.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Un enorme agujero negro encontrado en una galaxia lejana sin estrellas podría ser el primer ejemplo de un agujero negro primordial formado justo después del inicio del universo, abriendo nuevas formas de estudiar el cosmos.
